Levering Betrayal
It's not enough, apparently, for the University to
attack Wickwire's courses, budget and programs.
Hopkins now goes out of its way, into the city and into
the University's link to foundations, The Johns Hopkins
Fund, to hinder Levering Hall's fund-raising attempts.
When contributions from private and public sources are
drying up so rapidly, it is more than absurd, it is
malevolent, for University officials to deny this most
valuable of programs its access to funds.
One is at a loss to fathom the motives of Robert
Harvey in dissuading potential contributors to Levering
Hall, or those of George Benton in stalling the Fund in its
money-raising efforts. At one time, it was possible to
almost take seriously those who tried to limit Levering
Hall activities. There seemed to be nothing especially
irrational about trying to place programs and budget
under Dean Benton, or reduce Wickwire's course load,
or cut the budget slightly. But Wickwire's opponents are
now shown to have close to a pathological hatred of
tutoring, drug education, draft counseling, patient
advocacy, and the myriad of other activities that have
made Levering Hall so popular with students and so
respected by the citizens of Baltimore.
If and when Benton and Harvey and the other Hopkins
officials stop denying that they have made strenuous
efforts to damage Levering Hall, they will probably
contend that other parts of the University are more
deserving of financial aid. On the contrary, Levering
Hall is an important part of what Dr. Eisenhower likes
to call the vital core of the University. As such, it
deserves the support of University officials. And it
merits the backing cf faculty and students, with
financial contributions and the strong support of its
programs.

Activity Fee
Voting today on the SAC Tee increase referendum will
go a long way in determining the future of social activity
programs at Hopkins. SAC members and student
leaders are calling for a slight increase in the individual
fee to counteract the loss of $10,000 in university contributions.
If undergraduates are to enjoy any degree of social
activity at Hopkins, it is imperative that students vote
for the fee increase. A vote for the increase will result in
making money available to many student programs;
failure to do so will only underwrite the Administration's severe reduction in funding.
Students dissatisfied with the scope of this year's.
programs will be encouraged to note that the proposed
increase, small in terms of the individual, will generate
over $10,000 for expenditures next year. This amount
will enable the SAC to provide necessary funding for
many vital programs on campus.
Students who are interested in an expanded and more
satisfying undergraduate activities program should
vote for the SAC fee increase.

It's not enough, apparently, for the University to
attack Wickwire's courses, budget and programs.
Hopkins now goes out of its way, into the city and into

Fund, to hinder Levering Hall's fund-raising attempts.

drying up so rapidly, it is more than absurd, it is
malevolent, for University officials to deny this most
valuable of programs its access to funds.

Harvey in dissuading potential contributors to Levering
Hall, or those of George Benton in stalling the Fund in its
money-raising efforts. At one time, it was possible to
almost take seriously those who tried to limit Levering
Hall activities. There seemed to be nothing especially
irrational about trying to place programs and budget
under Dean Benton, or reduce Wickwire's course load,
or cut the budget slightly. But Wickwire's opponents are
now shown to have close to a pathological hatred of
tutoring, drug education, draft counseling, patient
advocacy, and the myriad of other activities that have
made Levering Hall so popular with students and so
respected by the citizens of Baltimore.

officials stop denying that they have made strenuous
efforts to damage Levering Hall, they will probably
contend that other parts of the University are more
deserving of financial aid. On the contrary, Levering
Hall is an important part of what Dr. Eisenhower likes
to call the vital core of the University. As such, it
deserves the support of University officials. And it
merits the backing cf faculty and students, with
financial contributions and the strong support of its
programs.
